Award.AbstractNarration:
****Technical Abstract****
One of the outstanding problems and challenges to condensed matter physics is to produce hydrogen in the metallic phase at ultra high pressures. Metallic hydrogen (MH) has been predicted to be a room temperature superconductor, and may be metastable, that is, it remains metallic when the pressure is released. If metastable MH would be the most powerful rocket propellant known. There are two pathways to MH: at high pressure hydrogen can be heated above the melting line to a new phase, the plasma phase transition, or PPT, where in the liquid phase it dissociates to become an atomic metallic liquid. The second pathway is to pressurize along a quasi-isotherm until it dissociates and becomes atomic metallic. Ultrahigh pressures are produced in diamond anvil cells and must be extended to pressures ~5 megabar to produce the predicted phases. Techniques have been developed for processing diamonds to increase their useful range of pressure and temperature with hydrogen samples. Using pulsed lasers, samples of hydrogen in the megabar pressure range have been heated to temperatures of a few thousand Kelvin and a phase transition has been observed. Measurements will be made to show that this phase is metallic or the PPT. Recent quasi-isothermal experiments have revealed a new phase above ~2 megabar, but not metallic. Experiments to study hydrogen to much higher pressures, beyond those of the new phase will be carried out by postdoctoral fellows, graduate, and undergraduate students in their educational development.

****Non-Technical Abstract****
The most prevalent element in the universe is hydrogen; pure hydrogen is found on earth bound together as diatomic molecules, that liquefy and solidify at very low temperatures as a transparent molecular insulator. For over 75 years it has been speculated that when pressurized, the molecules would dissociate to form an atomic solid or liquid that is metallic, with spectacular properties. These include room temperature superconductivity, existence of a liquid at absolute zero of temperature and millions of atmospheres pressure, superfluidity. Moreover metallic hydrogen is predicted to be metastable, that is, it would remain in the metallic phase when pressure is released, just as diamond made from carbon at high pressure does not revert to graphite when pressure is released. If metastable, metallic hydrogen would be the most powerful rocket fuel known and would revolutionize rocketry. Using diamond anvil cells to generate high pressures and optical techniques of study the pressure range will be extended, aiming to achieve pressures up to 4 to 5 million atmospheres and heating samples with lasers to thousands of degrees. Success in this program, carried out by postdoctoral fellows, graduate, and undergraduate students, and where possible high school students, will extend our knowledge and understanding of this simplest, but most complex atom in the periodic table of the elements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research project was to produce metallic hydrogen (MH) in the laboratory. Over 85 years ago Nobel Prize winner Eugene Wigner, along with Hillard Huntington, predicted that if solid molecular hydrogen were compressed to a pressure of a quarter of a million atmospheres (or equivalently, 0.25 megabars), the molecules would dissociate and form atomic MH. The hydrogen atom is the simplest of all elements, a single proton surrounded by an electron. On earth we find pure hydrogen as a gas in the form of molecules, two hydrogen atoms bonded together. If a gas of molecular hydrogen is cooled to low temperature it solidifies as an insulator. Modern theory predicts that pressures as high as 5 megabars are required for MH. 

One of the top three problems in physics, from a list by Nobel Prize Winner Vitaly Ginzburg, is making MH.  Another is room temperature superconductivity, that is, a metal that conducts electricity without dissipation or resistance to the flow of electrical current. Solid metallic hydrogen is predicted to be a room temperature superconductor!  Solid MH had never before existed on earth and probably not in the universe, although hydrogen is the most abundant element in the heavens.  The great outer planets like Jupiter are mainly composed of hydrogen. If hot enough, liquid atomic hydrogen is formed in the outer mantle of the planets (see Fig. 1). 

MH is predicted to be metastable. That is, if made at high pressure and the pressure is released, it will remain in the metallic phase.  If metallic hydrogen exists under ambient conditions and is superconducting, it could have an important impact on mankind?s energy problems.  A good percentage of our electrical power is lost in transporting energy from power generators to users. If transported over superconducting metallic hydrogen wires, there would be no losses.  Metastable metallic hydrogen contains enormous energy that is released if it is triggered to return to the molecular form. It is theoretically the most powerful rocket propellant known to man and would revolutionize rocketry.

Large static pressures are generated in diamond anvil cells (DACs), by compressing a sample between two diamonds, as seen in Figs. 2 and 3.   We have developed techniques that enable the generation of enormous pressures and successfully produced MH in the laboratory at almost 5 megabars. Figure 4 shows the development of a hydrogen sample with increasing pressure. As pressure is increased the sample goes from transparent, to black as it becomes a semiconductor, to shiny reflective. By fitting the reflectance to an accepted model, we determined that it is a metal. The phase diagram is in Fig. 5.  

A second way to make metallic hydrogen that does not require such a high pressure is to heat it to thousands of degrees Kelvin. Just as high density destabilizes the molecular bond of hydrogen, high temperatures weakens the bond and it dissociates to form liquid atomic metallic hydrogen.  The required pressures are of order 1 to 2 megabar.  The transition takes place abruptly as the sample is heated from a transparent molecular liquid to a reflective liquid metal.  The planet Jupiter is mostly MH in this form (Fig. 1).  As one descends into Jupiter's atmosphere, the pressure and temperature increase until hydrogen becomes metallic. It is this metal that gives rise to Jupiter's magnetic field.

It is important to know the temperature and pressure at which the transition to liquid atomic MH takes place.  The materials that are used to make a DAC can only sustain temperatures above ~1000 K for very short periods of time. Thus, we pressurized hydrogen in a DAC, and it was heated by a laser with pulses a few hundred nanoseconds long. This is sufficiently long for the sample to make the transition. By using time resolved spectroscopy, we could observe the reflectance of the sample as a function of time.  The onset of metallic reflectance can signify the transition pressure and temperature. Measurements were made as function of pressure to determine the phase line (Fig. 5), as well as properties of the metallic phase.  Subsequently, deuterium was studied, and the phase line was found at a higher temperature (as expected).  Thus, there is a large isotope effect--that is, the phase lines for hydrogen and deuterium are very distinct. 

Accurate determination of ultra-high pressures is challenging. We are currently studying the shift of the fluorescence lines in nitrogen vacancy diamond as a pressure gauge. Nano NV diamond particles will be embedded in the sample and the fluorescence determined at high pressure. Preliminary measurements at ambient pressure are shown in Fig. 6.

In summary, we have studied hydrogen and its isotope, deuterium, in the laboratory.  We have observed both the low temperature very high-pressure transition and the high temperature transition to liquid metallic hydrogen (Fig. 5).
